sentences: On returning to Hull, P-Orridge founded COUM Transmissions with Cosey Fanni Tutti, and in 1973 they relocated to London.
COUM's 1976 Prostitution show at London's Institute of Contemporary Arts was particularly vilified by tabloids, gaining them the moniker of the "wreckers of civilisation."
P-Orridge's band, Throbbing Gristle, grew out of COUM, and were active from 1975 to 1981 as pioneers in the industrial music genre.
In 1981, P-Orridge co-founded Psychic TV, an experimental band that from 1988 onward came under the increasing influence of acid house.
In 1981, P-Orridge co-founded Psychic TV, an experimental band that from 1988 onward came under the increasing influence of acid house.
In 1981, P-Orridge co-founded Thee Temple ov
P-Orridge was often seen as the group's leader, but rejected that position, and left the group in 1991.

There, P-Orridge married Jacqueline Breyer, later known as Lady Jaye, in 1995, and together they embarked on the Pandrogeny Project, an attempt to unite as a "pandrogyne", or single entity, through the use of surgical body modification to physically resemble one another.
P-Orridge continued with this project of body modification after Lady Jaye's 2007 death.
Although involved in reunions of both Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV in the 2000s, P-Orridge retired from music to focus on other artistic mediums in 2009.
Although involved in reunions of both Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV in the 2000s, P-Orridge retired from music to focus on other artistic mediums in 2009.

section: == Early life == | === 1950–1964: Childhood ===

sentences: Genesis P-Orridge was born Neil Andrew Megson on 22 February 1950 in Victoria Park, Manchester, to Ronald and Muriel Megson.
section: == Early life == | === 1950–1964: Childhood ===

sentences: Muriel was from Salford and had first met Ronald after he returned to England after being injured with the British Army at the Battle of Dunkirk in 1940.
section: == Early life == | === 1950–1964: Childhood ===

sentences: Passing the 11-plus exam, P-Orridge won a scholarship to attend Stockport Grammar School, doing so between 1961 and 1964.
section: == Early life == | === 1950–1964: Childhood ===
== Early life == | === 1964–1968: Solihull School and Worm ===

sentences: After their father gained employment as the Midlands area manager of a cleaning and maintenance business, P-Orridge was sent to the privately run Solihull School in Warwickshire between 1964 and 1968; a period they would refer to as "basically four years of being mentally and physically tortured", but also a time when they developed an interest in art, occultism and the avant-garde.
section: == Early life == | === 1964–1968: Solihull School and Worm ===

sentences: In 1967, P-Orridge founded their first collective, Worm, with school friends Pingle Wad (Peter Winstanley), Spydeee Gasmantell (Ian Evetts) and P-Orridge's girlfriend Jane Ray.
section: == Early life == | === 1964–1968: Solihull School and Worm ===

sentences: Worm was influenced by AMM and John Cage's 1961 book Silence: Lectures and Writings.
section: == Early life == | === 1964–1968: Solihull School and Worm ===

sentences: In 1966, P-Orridge, Evetts, Hermon, Wolfson, and Winstanley began production of an underground magazine, entitled Conscience.
section: == Early life == | === 1964–1968: Solihull School and Worm ===

sentences: The Knights undertook a happening on 1 June 1968 which they titled Beautiful Litter.
section: == Early life == | === 1964–1968: Solihull School and Worm ===
== Early life == | === 1968–1969: Hull University and Transmedia Explorations ===

sentences: In September 1968, P-Orridge began studying for a degree in Social Administration and Philosophy at the University of Hull.
section: == Early life == | === 1968–1969: Hull University and Transmedia Explorations ===

sentences: Three issues were published between 1968 and 1970 before the Hull Student's Union banned the publication, considering it legally obscene and fearing prosecution.
section: == Early life == | === 1968–1969: Hull University and Transmedia Explorations ===

sentences: Developing a keen interest in poetry, P-Orridge won the 1969 Hull University Needler Poetry Competition, judged by Compton lecturer Richard Murphy and the poet Philip Larkin, who was then librarian at the university.
section: == Early life == | === 1968–1969: Hull University and Transmedia Explorations ===

sentences: P-Orridge became involved in radical student politics through their friendship with Tom Fawthrop, a member of the Radical Student Alliance who had led a student occupation of the university's administrative buildings as a part of the worldwide student protests of 1968.
section: == Early life == | === 1968–1969: Hull University and Transmedia Explorations ===

sentences: In 1969, P-Orridge attempted to reconstruct the occupation for a film, in the hopes that it would itself become a genuine protest occupation, but this venture failed due to a lack of participants.
section: == Early life == | === 1968–1969: Hull University and Transmedia Explorations ===

sentences: In 1969, P-Orridge dropped out of university and moved to London, and joined the Transmedia Explorations commune, who were then living in a large run-down house in Islington Park Street.
section: == Early life == | === 1968–1969: Hull University and Transmedia Explorations ===

sentences: The group, initiated by the artist David Medalla and initially named the Exploding Galaxy, had been at the forefront of the London hippy scene since 1967, but had partially disbanded after a series of police raids and a damaging court case.
section: == Early life == | === 1968–1969: Hull University and Transmedia Explorations ===

section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1969–1970: Founding COUM Transmissions ===

sentences: In November 1969, P-Orridge returned to Hull to meet up with friend John Shapeero, who partnered with P-Orridge to turn COUM Transmissions into an avant-garde artistic and musical troupe.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1969–1970: Founding COUM Transmissions ===

sentences: The latter combined the names of Anthony Burgess' dystopian science-fiction novel A Clockwork Orange (1962) with Tom Wolfe's The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test (1968), a work of literary journalism devoted to the Merry Pranksters, a US communal counter-cultural group who advocated the use of psychedelic drugs.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1969–1970: Founding COUM Transmissions ===

section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1969–1970: Founding COUM Transmissions ===

sentences: In December 1969, P-Orridge and Shapiro moved out of their flat and into a former fruit warehouse in Hull's docking area, overlooking the Humber.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1969–1970: Founding COUM Transmissions ===

sentences: Having earlier befriended them at an acid test party, Newby became P-Orridge's roommate at the Funhouse, first taking the name Cosmosis, but latterly adopting the stage name Cosey Fanni Tutti after the title of Amadeus Mozart's 1790 opera Così fan tutte.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1969–1970: Founding COUM Transmissions ===
== COUM Transmissions == | === 1971–1973: Activities in Hull ===

sentences: On 5 January 1971, P-Orridge underwent a legal name change to Genesis P-Orridge by deed poll, combining the adopted nickname Genesis with an altered spelling of porridge, the foodstuff which they had lived off as a student.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1971–1973: Activities in Hull ===

sentences: In April 1971, COUM, consisting of P'Orridge and Gasmantell, broadcast their first live radio session, for the On Cue programme for Radio Humberside.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1971–1973: Activities in Hull ===

sentences: As they gained coverage in the music press, interest in the band grew, and they supported Hawkwind at St. George's Hall in Bradford in October 1971, where they performed a piece called Edna and the Great Surfers, where they led the crowd in shouting "Off, Off, Off".
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1971–1973: Activities in Hull ===

sentences: They entered the National Rock/Folk Contest at Hull's New Grange Club with a set titled This Machine Kills Music, and organised events for Hull City Council's celebrations to mark the UK's entry into the European Economic Community in 1973.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1971–1973: Activities in Hull ===

sentences: Meanwhile, P-Orridge created the character of Alien Brain, and in July 1972, performed as the character at an event entitled the World Premiere of the Alien Brain, at Hull Arts Centre.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1971–1973: Activities in Hull ===

sentences: COUM also began publishing books; in 1972, they brought out the first volume of The Million and One Names of COUM, part of a proposed project to release 1001 slogans (such as "A thousand and one ways to COUM" and "COUM are Fab and Kinky"), while in 1973 P-Orridge published Copyright Breeches, which explored an ongoing personal fascination with the copyright symbol and its implications for art and society.

== COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: 1973 saw COUM take part in the Fluxshoe retrospective that toured Britain exhibiting the work of the Fluxus artists; it was organised by David Mayor, who befriended P-Orridge.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: P-Orrdige's first film, Wundatrek Tours, was released in September 1973, and documented a day out to Brighton.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: In January 1974, COUM returned their attention to music, collaborating with the Canadian artist Clive Robertson to produce Marcel Duchamp's Next Work, which they premiered at an arts festival in the Zwarte Zaal Royal Conservatory of Ghent in Ghent, Belgium.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: COUM's next major work was Couming of Age, performed in March 1974 at the Oval House in Kennington, South London.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: In May 1974, COUM issued a manifesto published on an A3 double-sided sheet titled Decoumpositions and Events.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: In April 1974, the Arts Council of Great Britain gave COUM the first half of a £1,500 grant.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: During that year, they made use of various artist-run venues in London, most notably the Art Meeting Place (AMP) in Covent Garden, where they regularly performed during 1974.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: In August 1974 they carried out a spontaneous unauthorised piece of performance art in Brook Green, Hammersmith; during the performance, police arrived and put a stop to the event, deeming it obscene.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: In September 1974, COUM were invited to attend the Stadfest in Rottweil, West Germany, and they proceeded with a travel grant from the British Council.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: In February 1975, P-Orridge gained their first full-time job, working as an assistant editor at St. James Press, in which they helped to compile the Contemporary Artists reference book.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: In March 1975, COUM performed Couming of Youth at the Melkweg in Amsterdam.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===

sentences: At Southampton's Nuffield Festival in July 1975, COUM performed Studio of Lust, where P-Orridge publicly masturbated and all of the members undressed and adopted sexual poses.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1973–1975: London and growing fame ===
== COUM Transmissions == | === 1975–1976: Establishing Throbbing Gristle and the Prostitution show ===

sentences: COUM were introduced to Chris Carter in 1975 through their mutual friend John Lacey.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1975–1976: Establishing Throbbing Gristle and the Prostitution show ===

sentences: Together, Carter, Christopherson, Cosey and P-Orridge founded a musical band, Throbbing Gristle, on 3 September 1975; they had deliberately chosen that date for it was the 36th anniversary of the United Kingdom joining the Second World War.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1975–1976: Establishing Throbbing Gristle and the Prostitution show ===

sentences: COUM continued to operate alongside TG, and in October 1975 they performed Jusquà la balle crystal at the Ninth Paris Biennale at the Musée d'art modern.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1975–1976: Establishing Throbbing Gristle and the Prostitution show ===

sentences: They were prosecuted in 1975 for making collages combining postcards of Queen Elizabeth with soft-core porn, but the jail term and fines were suspended on condition they did not continue.
section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1975–1976: Establishing Throbbing Gristle and the Prostitution show ===

section: == COUM Transmissions == | === 1975–1976: Establishing Throbbing Gristle and the Prostitution show ===

sentences: Throbbing Gristle was formed in late 1975 as a four-piece band, consisting of P-Orridge, Cosey Fanni Tutti, Peter "Sleazy" Christopherson and Chris Carter.
section: == Throbbing Gristle ==

sentences: The first Throbbing Gristle performance was held at the Air Gallery in London in July 1976.
section: == Throbbing Gristle ==

sentences: Throbbing Gristle released "Discipline" in 1980.
section: == Throbbing Gristle ==

sentences: Throbbing Gristle's best-selling single was "Zyklon B Zombie" (1978), the title being a reference to the Zyklon B poison gas used at Auschwitz extermination camp.
section: == Throbbing Gristle ==

sentences: The final Throbbing Gristle live event, Mission of Dead Souls, occurred in May 1981 at the Kezar Pavilion in San Francisco.
section: == Throbbing Gristle ==

sentences: Through an introduction provided by Burroughs, P-Orridge met Brion Gysin in Paris, probably in 1980, coming to be deeply influenced by Gysin's cut-up method; P-Orridge understood this to be a revolutionary method of escaping current patterns of thought and developing something new.
section: == Throbbing Gristle ==

sentences: Following the break-up of Throbbing Gristle, in 1981 P-Orridge founded a band with Peter Christopherson and Alex Fergusson that they named Psychic TV.
section: == Psychic TV and Thee Temple Ov Psychic Youth ==

sentences: For their first album, Force the Hand of Chance (1982), P-Orridge used a kangling, or Tibetan trumpet made out of a human thigh-bone; the instrument had been introduced to P-Orridge by David Tibet, and attracted attention to their music.
section: == Psychic TV and Thee Temple Ov Psychic Youth ==

sentences: From 1988, the band came under the increasing influence of the acid house genre of dance music, and were responsible for helping the popularisation of acid house music in Europe.
section: == Psychic TV and Thee Temple Ov Psychic Youth ==

sentences: Psychic TV made its debut in 1982 at an event organised by P-Orridge, David Dawson, and Roger Ely, called The Final Academy.

section: == Later life == | === 2009–2020: Semi-retirement, illness and death ===

sentences: On 4 November 2009 it was announced that P-Orridge would retire from touring in any and all bands (including Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV) to concentrate on art, writing and music.

sentences: In June 2010, P-Orridge sold the Ridgewood property, holding a garage sale in the basement of a local art gallery to sell off a range of personal items, in addition to an array of dildos.
section: == Later life == | === 2009–2020: Semi-retirement, illness and death ===

sentences: P-Orridge visited Australia for the first (and only) time in 2012, performing two live shows with Psychic TV; one as part of the Adelaide Festival, and another secret show in Melbourne following a screening of the documentary film The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye.
section: == Later life == | === 2009–2020: Semi-retirement, illness and death ===

sentences: P-Orridge returned to regular touring with Psychic TV in 2016, in support of the release of their album Alienist.
section: == Later life == | === 2009–2020: Semi-retirement, illness and death ===

sentences: In August 2015, P-Orridge gained publicity for an interview critical of Caitlyn Jenner's self-description as a "spokesperson" for the transgender community, stating that Jenner was "clueless" and did not know what life was like for the majority of transgender people around the world.
section: == Later life == | === 2009–2020: Semi-retirement, illness and death ===

sentences: In June 2016, P-Orridge was featured as a model in a campaign by the designer Marc Jacobs, who described P-Orridge as "a sort of come-to-life definition of realness and authenticity".
section: == Later life == | === 2009–2020: Semi-retirement, illness and death ===

sentences: P-Orridge was diagnosed with chronic myelomonocytic leukaemia in October 2017, and died in New York City on 14 March 2020, aged 70.

sentences: Genesis Breyer P-Orridge (born Neil Andrew Megson; 22 February 1950 – 14 March 2020) was an English singer-songwriter, musician, poet, performance artist, visual artist,  and occultist who rose to notability as the founder of the COUM Transmissions artistic collective and lead vocalist of seminal industrial band Throbbing Gristle.

sentences: Asserting that their "industrial paganism" was different from most forms of contemporary paganism, Partridge described it as "confrontational, subversive, experimental and, to a large extent, dystopian", with it serving as "an ideological tool" with which to analyse society "from its underbelly; an immersion in the dark side; the subversion of Christian hegemony, conservative politics and what nowadays might be described as neoliberalism".
